items.name: FIGMA_CREATE_MODIFY_DELETE_VARIABLES
items.description: Manages variables, collections, modes, and their values in a figma file via batch create/update/delete operations; use temporary ids to link new related items in one request and ensure `variablemodevalues` match the target variable's `resolvedtype`.

parameters.description: Request schema for creating, modifying, or deleting variables, variable collections, and modes.

file_key.description: The key of the Figma file or branch to modify variables in. Use `GET /v1/files/:key` with the `branch_data=true` query parameter to obtain a branch key.
file_key.title: File Key

variableCollections.description: List of operations for variable collections, each a dict with 'action' ('CREATE', 'UPDATE', 'DELETE'). For 'CREATE', include 'name' (temp 'id' optional). For 'UPDATE', 'id' and fields to modify. For 'DELETE', 'id'. See Figma API's `VariableCollectionMutation` for details.
variableCollections.title: Variable Collections

variableModeValues.description: A list of specific values to set for variables in particular modes. Each item links a variable and a mode to a new value.

items.description: Request schema for setting a specific value for a variable in a given mode.

modeId.description: The ID of the mode in which to set the variable's value. This mode must belong to the variable collection containing the target variable.
modeId.title: Mode Id

value.description: The value to set for the variable in the specified mode. While this field is typed as boolean in the schema, the actual value provided must match the variable's `resolvedType` (e.g., STRING, FLOAT, COLOR, BOOLEAN). If setting to a variable alias, the alias must also resolve to this type. For non-boolean types, refer to Figma API documentation for the correct value structure if issues arise with this boolean-typed field.
value.title: Value

variableId.description: The ID of the target variable. A temporary ID can be used if the variable is being created in the same request.
variableId.title: Variable Id

items.title: CreateModifyDeleteVariablesvariableModeValuesRequest

variableModeValues.title: Variable Mode Values

variableModes.description: List of operations for modes, each a dict with 'action' ('CREATE', 'UPDATE', 'DELETE'). For 'CREATE', include 'variableCollectionId', 'name' (temp 'id' optional). For 'UPDATE', 'id' and 'name'. For 'DELETE', 'id'. See Figma API's `VariableModeMutation` for details.
variableModes.title: Variable Modes

variables.description: List of operations for variables, each a dict with 'action' ('CREATE', 'UPDATE', 'DELETE'). For 'CREATE', include 'variableCollectionId', 'name', 'resolvedType' (temp 'id' optional). For 'UPDATE', 'id' and fields to modify. For 'DELETE', 'id'. See Figma API's `VariableMutation` for details.
variables.title: Variables

items.name: FIGMA_DISCOVER_FIGMA_RESOURCES
items.description: üîç smart figma resource discovery - never guess ids again! üéØ easiest method: just paste any figma url to get all ids: ‚Ä¢ file urls: https://www.figma.com/file/abc123/design ‚Üí get file key ‚Ä¢ design urls: https://www.figma.com/design/abc123/design ‚Üí get file key ‚Ä¢ node urls: ...?node-id=123:456 ‚Üí get file key + node id ‚Ä¢ team urls: .../team/123456/... ‚Üí get team id üîÑ step-by-step discovery: 1. team id ‚Üí projects list (with project ids) 2. project id ‚Üí files list (with file keys + thumbnails) 3. file key ‚Üí nodes list (with node ids + hierarchy) üí° common workflows: ‚Ä¢ extract from url: discoverfigmaresources(figma url="...") ‚Ä¢ browse team: discoverfigmaresources(team id="123") ‚Ä¢ list files: discoverfigmaresources(project id="proj 456") ‚Ä¢ find nodes: discoverfigmaresources(file key="abc123") ‚ú® get file key for getfilejson, node ids for detectbackground, etc.

parameters.description: Request to discover Figma resources and extract IDs automatically.

figma_url.description:
Full Figma URL to extract file_key, node_id, and team_id from. Works with any Figma URL format:
‚Ä¢ File: https://www.figma.com/file/ABC123/Design-Name
‚Ä¢ Design: https://www.figma.com/design/ABC123/Design-Name
‚Ä¢ With node: https://www.figma.com/file/ABC123/Design?node-id=123:456
‚Ä¢ Team: https://www.figma.com/files/team/123456/Team-Name
This is the easiest way to get all IDs you need!
figma_url.title: Figma Url

file_key.description: File key to extract all node IDs from. Get this from file URL (figma.com/file/FILE_KEY/...) or from project files list. Returns hierarchical list of all nodes with IDs, names, types, and paths.
file_key.title: File Key

max_depth.description: Maximum tree depth to traverse when discovering nodes. 2=pages+frames, 3=pages+frames+components, etc. Higher values find more nodes but take longer.
max_depth.title: Max Depth

project_id.description: Project ID to list all files from. Get this from project URL or from team projects list. Returns files with keys, names, and thumbnails.
project_id.title: Project Id

team_id.description: Team ID to list all projects from. Get this from team URL: https://www.figma.com/files/team/YOUR_TEAM_ID/Team-Name. Returns list of projects with IDs and names.
team_id.title: Team Id

items.description: Retrieves detailed information about a specific webhook by its id, provided the webhook exists and is accessible to the user.

description.description: An optional, user-provided description or name for the webhook. This can help in managing multiple webhooks. Maximum length is 140 characters.

items.name: FIGMA_GET_COMMENTS_IN_A_FILE
items.description: Retrieves all comments from an existing figma file, identified by a valid `file key`, returning details like content, author, position, and reactions, with an option for markdown formatted content.

parameters.description: Request schema for `GetCommentsInAFile` action. Specifies the file and formatting options for retrieving comments.

as_md.description: If true, comment content will be returned in Markdown format where applicable (e.g., for links, bold text). Defaults to false, returning rich text structure.
as_md.title: As Md

file_key.description: Identifier for the Figma file from which to retrieve comments. This can be a file key (a unique string identifying a file) or a branch key. To obtain a branch key, use the `GET /v1/files/:key` endpoint with the `branch_data` query parameter.
file_key.title: File Key

parameters.title: GetCommentsInAFileRequest

data.description: Wrapper object containing the list of comments.

comments.description: A list of comment objects retrieved from the Figma file.

client_meta.description:
Positioning data for the comment, detailing its location and type (point or region) on the canvas. The structure of this field varies based on how the comment is placed:
- `ClientMeta`: Absolute canvas coordinates (x, y) for a point comment.
- `ClientMeta1`: Node-relative offset (`node_id`, `node_offset`) for a point comment.
- `ClientMeta2`: Absolute canvas coordinates (`x`, `y` for an anchor corner), region dimensions (`region_width`, `region_height`), and `comment_pin_corner` for a region comment.
- `ClientMeta3`: Node-relative offset (`node_id`, `node_offset` for an anchor corner), region dimensions, and `comment_pin_corner` for a region comment.

x.description: The X coordinate of a vector, typically representing an absolute position on the Figma canvas.
x.title: X

y.description: The Y coordinate of a vector, typically representing an absolute position on the Figma canvas.
y.title: Y

client_meta.title: ClientMeta

created_at.description: Timestamp in UTC ISO 8601 format indicating when the comment was created.
created_at.title: Created At

file_key.description: Identifier of the Figma file containing this comment.
file_key.title: File Key

message.description: The text content of the comment. May include mentions or rich text elements if `as_md` is false, or Markdown content if `as_md` is true.
message.title: Message

order_id.description: A string representing the numerical identifier (e.g., '1', '2') displayed with the comment in the Figma UI. This is typically present only for top-level comments and reflects their visible ordering.
order_id.title: Order Id

parent_id.description: Identifier of the parent comment if this comment is a reply. Null or absent for top-level comments.
parent_id.title: Parent Id

reactions.description: A list of all reactions made to this comment.

created_at.description: Timestamp in UTC ISO 8601 format indicating when the reaction was added.
created_at.title: Created At

emoji.description: The emoji reaction, represented as a shortcode (e.g., `:heart:`, `:+1::skin-tone-2:`). For a list of accepted emoji shortcodes and information on skin tone modifiers, refer to the linked resource: [emoji list](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/missive/emoji-mart/main/packages/emoji-mart-data/sets/14/native.json).
emoji.title: Emoji

user.description: Details of the user who added the reaction.

handle.description: Display name or handle of the Figma user.
handle.title: Handle

id.description: Unique and stable identifier for the Figma user.
id.title: Id

img_url.description: URL of the user's profile image.
img_url.title: Img Url

user.title: User

reactions.title: Reactions

resolved_at.description: Timestamp in UTC ISO 8601 format indicating when the comment was resolved. Null or absent if the comment is not resolved.
resolved_at.title: Resolved At

user.description: Details of the user who created the comment.

handle.description: Display name or handle of the Figma user.
handle.title: Handle

id.description: Unique and stable identifier for the Figma user.
id.title: Id

img_url.description: URL of the user's profile image.
img_url.title: Img Url

user.title: User

comments.title: Comments

data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: FIGMA_GET_LOCAL_VARIABLES
items.description: Retrieves all local/remote variables for a figma file/branch; crucial for obtaining mode-specific values which `/v1/files/{file key}/variables/published` omits.

parameters.description: Request schema for `GetLocalVariables`

file_key.description: Key of the Figma file or branch. Can be a standard file key or a branch-specific key (to obtain a branch key, use `GET /v1/files/:key` with the `branch_data` query parameter).
file_key.title: File Key

parameters.title: GetLocalVariablesRequest

data.description: The structured response data containing the status, error indicator, and the local variables metadata.

error.description: Boolean indicating if an error occurred. `false` for successful requests.
error.title: Error

defaultModeId.description: The identifier of the mode that is considered the default for this variable collection.
defaultModeId.title: Defaultmodeid

hiddenFromPublishing.description: Indicates if this entire variable collection is hidden when publishing the current file as a library.
hiddenFromPublishing.title: Hiddenfrompublishing

id.description: A unique string identifier for this variable collection.
id.title: Id

key.description: The unique, machine-readable key for this variable collection.
key.title: Key

modes.description: A list of `Mode` objects defined within this variable collection.

modeId.description: A unique string identifier for this mode within its variable collection.
modeId.title: Modeid

name.description: The user-facing display name of this mode (e.g., 'Light', 'Dark').
name.title: Name

modes.title: Modes

name.description: The user-facing display name of this variable collection.
name.title: Name

remote.description: Indicates if this variable collection is remote (i.e., imported from another Figma library file).
remote.title: Remote

variableIds.description: An ordered list of string identifiers for variables belonging to this collection. The order generally mirrors the Figma Design UI but does not account for variable groups, so it might not precisely match the visual ordering and grouping.
variableIds.title: Variableids

variableCollections.description: A dictionary where keys are variable collection IDs (strings) and values are the corresponding `VariableCollections` objects.
variableCollections.title: Variable Collections

codeSyntax.description: An object providing platform-specific code representations for the variable (e.g., for Web, Android, iOS). All platform fields are optional.
codeSyntax.title: CodeSyntax

deletedButReferenced.description: Optional. If `true`, signifies that the variable was deleted within the Figma editor, yet the document might still contain references to it. Such references can occur through bound values or variable aliases. Defaults to `false` if not present.
deletedButReferenced.title: Deletedbutreferenced

description.description: A user-provided description for the variable.
description.title: Description

hiddenFromPublishing.description: Indicates if this variable is hidden when publishing the current file as a library. For a variable to be publishable, both the variable itself and its parent `VariableCollection` must have `hiddenFromPublishing` set to `false`.
hiddenFromPublishing.title: Hiddenfrompublishing

id.description: A unique string identifier for this variable.
id.title: Id

key.description: The unique, machine-readable key for this variable, often used for programmatic access or referencing.
key.title: Key

name.description: The user-facing display name of this variable.
name.title: Name

remote.description: Indicates if this variable is a remote variable (i.e., imported from a library).
remote.title: Remote

resolvedType.description: The resolved data type of the variable, such as BOOLEAN, FLOAT, STRING, or COLOR.
resolvedType.title: ResolvedType

scopes.description: A list of scopes defining where this variable is displayed in the Figma UI's variable picker (e.g., `TEXT_CONTENT`, `CORNER_RADIUS`). This setting controls visibility in the UI picker only and does not prevent the variable from being bound in other scopes programmatically via the API.
scopes.title: Scopes

a.description: Alpha (opacity) channel value, normalized between 0.0 and 1.0.
a.title: A

b.description: Blue color channel value, normalized between 0.0 and 1.0.
b.title: B

g.description: Green color channel value, normalized between 0.0 and 1.0.
g.title: G

r.description: Red color channel value, normalized between 0.0 and 1.0.
r.title: R

id.description: The ID of the variable to which the current variable is aliased. This aliased variable can be either local or remote. Details for both types can be retrieved using the `GET /v1/files/:file_key/variables/local` endpoint (this same endpoint).
id.title: Id

valuesByMode.description: A dictionary mapping mode IDs to their corresponding values for this variable. The value's structure depends on the `resolvedType` (e.g., boolean, float, string, RGBA color object, or variable alias object).
valuesByMode.title: Valuesbymode

variableCollectionId.description: The unique identifier of the `VariableCollection` to which this variable belongs.
variableCollectionId.title: Variablecollectionid

variables.description: A dictionary where keys are variable IDs (strings) and values are the corresponding `Variables` objects containing their full details.
variables.title: Variables

status.description: The HTTP status code of the response, e.g., 200 for success.
status.title: Status

data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: FIGMA_GET_PAYMENTS
items.description: Retrieves a user's payment information for a figma plugin, widget, or community file; the authenticated identity must own the resource.

parameters.description: Request schema for `GetPayments`

community_file_id.description: ID of the Community file. Obtain from its Community page URL (number after 'file/'). If `user_id` is provided, specify exactly one of `community_file_id`, `plugin_id`, or `widget_id`.
community_file_id.title: Community File Id

plugin_id.description: ID of the plugin. Obtain from its manifest or Community page URL (number after 'plugin/'). If `user_id` is provided, specify exactly one of `community_file_id`, `plugin_id`, or `widget_id`.
plugin_id.title: Plugin Id

plugin_payment_token.description: Short-lived auth token from `getPluginPaymentTokenAsync` (Figma Plugin Payments API). See Figma docs 'Calling the Payments REST API...'. If provided, `user_id` and resource IDs are typically not needed.
plugin_payment_token.title: Plugin Payment Token

user_id.description: ID of the user whose payment information is sought. Obtain via OAuth2 with Figma REST API. Required if `plugin_payment_token` is not provided.
user_id.title: User Id

widget_id.description: ID of the widget. Obtain from its manifest or Community page URL (number after 'widget/'). If `user_id` is provided, specify exactly one of `community_file_id`, `plugin_id`, or `widget_id`.
widget_id.title: Widget Id

parameters.title: GetPaymentsRequest

data.description: Contains the detailed payment information for the user and resource, including status, error, and metadata.

error.description: For successful requests, this value is always `false`.
error.title: Error

meta.description: An object describing a user's payment information for a plugin, widget, or Community file.

date_of_purchase.description:
The UTC ISO 8601 timestamp indicating when the user purchased the resource. No value is given if the user has never purchased the resource.
  
Note that a value will still be returned if the user had purchased the resource, but no longer has active access to it (e.g. purchase refunded, subscription ended).
date_of_purchase.title: Date Of Purchase

payment_status.description: An object describing the user's payment status.

type.description:
The current payment status of the user on the resource, as a string enum:
  
- `UNPAID`: user has not paid for the resource
- `PAID`: user has an active purchase on the resource
- `TRIAL`: user is in the trial period for a subscription resource
type.title: Type

payment_status.title: Payment Status

resource_id.description: ID of the queried plugin, widget, or Community file. Can be used for response validation.
resource_id.title: Resource Id

user_id.description: ID of the user whose payment information was queried. Can be used for response validation.
user_id.title: User Id

meta.title: Meta

status.description: The response status code.
status.title: Status

data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: FIGMA_RENDER_IMAGES_OF_FILE_NODES
items.description: Renders specified nodes from a figma file as images (jpg, pdf, png, svg), returning a map of node ids to image urls (or `null` for failed nodes); images expire after 30 days and are capped at 32 megapixels (larger requests are scaled down).

parameters.description: Request model for rendering images of specified nodes within a Figma file.

contents_only.description: If true, excludes content overlapping node boundaries. If false, includes overlapping content (may increase processing time).
contents_only.title: Contents Only

file_key.description: Key of the Figma file or branch. To obtain a branch key, use the `GET /v1/files/:key` endpoint with the `branch_data=true` query parameter.
file_key.title: File Key

format.description: Desired output format for the rendered images.
format.title: Format

ids.description: Comma-separated list of node IDs to render as images (e.g., '1:2,1:3,1:4').
ids.title: Ids

scale.description: Image scaling factor, a number between 0.01 and 4 (e.g., 2 renders at twice original size).
scale.title: Scale

svg_include_id.description: (SVG format only) If true, includes `id` attributes (using layer name) for all SVG elements.
svg_include_id.title: Svg Include Id

svg_include_node_id.description: (SVG format only) If true, includes `data-node-id` attribute (with node ID) for all SVG elements.
svg_include_node_id.title: Svg Include Node Id

svg_outline_text.description: (SVG format only) If true, text is rendered as vector paths (outlines) for visual fidelity. If false, text is rendered as `<text>` elements (selectable, appearance may vary).
svg_outline_text.title: Svg Outline Text

svg_simplify_stroke.description: (SVG format only) If true, simplifies inside/outside strokes, using `stroke` attribute instead of `<mask>` where possible.
svg_simplify_stroke.title: Svg Simplify Stroke

use_absolute_bounds.description: If true, uses full node dimensions for rendering, ignoring cropping/empty space (useful for text nodes without unintended cropping).
use_absolute_bounds.title: Use Absolute Bounds

version.description: Specific version ID of the file to render; if omitted, the current version is used.
version.title: Version

parameters.title: RenderImagesOfFileNodesRequest

data.description: Core response data with image rendering results.

err.description: Always `null` if overall request was successful. Check `images` map for node-specific rendering status.
err.title: Err

images.description: Maps each requested node ID to its rendered image URL. A `null` value signifies rendering failure for that node (e.g., ID non-existent, node unrenderable). All input `ids` are present as keys.
images.title: Images

data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_COMPARE_TWO_COMMITS
items.description: Compares two commit points (commits, branches, tags, or shas) within a repository or across forks, using `base...head` or `owner:ref...owner:ref` format for the `basehead` parameter.

parameters.description: Request schema for `CompareTwoCommits` action. Specifies the repository and the two commit points (base and head) to compare.

basehead.description: A string specifying the base and head references to compare, in the format `BASE...HEAD`. `BASE` and `HEAD` can be branch names (e.g., `main...develop`), tag names (e.g., `v1.0.0...v1.1.0`), or commit SHA-1s. Both references must exist in the specified repository. To compare branches across forks in the same network, use the format `OWNER:REF...OWNER:REF` (e.g., `octocat:main...another-user:main`).
basehead.title: Basehead

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

page.description: Page number of the results to fetch, for pagination when the number of differences (commits or files) is large.
page.title: Page

per_page.description: Number of results (e.g., files or commits) to return per page, with a maximum of 100, for pagination.
per_page.title: Per Page

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

parameters.title: CompareTwoCommitsRequest

data.description: A dictionary containing the comparison details. This typically includes: the status of the comparison (e.g., 'diverged', 'ahead', 'behind', 'identical'), the number of commits `ahead_by` and `behind_by` the base, `total_commits` in the range, an array of `commits` objects, an array of `files` objects detailing changed files (including status, additions, deletions, changes, patch, etc.), and various URLs (`html_url`, `permalink_url`, `diff_url`, `patch_url`) for accessing the comparison.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CHECK_RUN
items.description: Creates a new check run for a specific commit in a repository, used by external services to report status, detailed feedback, annotations, and images directly within the github ui.

parameters.description: Request schema to create a new check run on GitHub.

actions.description: A list of up to three action objects defining interactive buttons displayed on GitHub after the check run completes. Each object needs a `label` (button text), `identifier` (unique ID for the action), and `description` (tooltip). Clicking a button sends a `check_run.requested_action` webhook to your app.
actions.title: Actions

completed_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run finished. **Required if `status` is `completed`**.
completed_at.title: Completed At

conclusion.description: **Required if `completed_at` is provided or if `status` is `completed`**. Specifies the final outcome of the check (e.g., 'success', 'failure'). Note: Setting `conclusion` automatically sets `status` to `completed`. GitHub alone can set a conclusion to `stale`.
conclusion.title: Conclusion

details_url.description: The URL of the integrator's site providing full details of the check. If omitted, the GitHub App's homepage is used. This URL is available from the check's UI.
details_url.title: Details Url

external_id.description: A unique identifier for the check run on the integrator's system. This helps in correlating check runs between GitHub and the external system.
external_id.title: External Id

head_sha.description: The SHA of the commit for which the check run is created.
head_sha.title: Head Sha

name.description: The name of the check to be displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, "Code Coverage" or "Linter".
name.title: Name

output__annotations.description: A list of annotation objects detailing issues at specific code locations. Annotations are visible in the 'Checks' and 'Files changed' tabs of a pull request. Each annotation object should specify `path`, `start_line`, `end_line`, `annotation_level` ('notice', 'warning', or 'failure'), and `message`. Optional fields include `start_column`, `end_column`, `title`, and `raw_details`. Up to 50 annotations per API request; for more, use subsequent 'Update a check run' calls. GitHub Actions limits are 10 warnings and 10 errors per step.
output__annotations.title: Output  Annotations

output__images.description: A list of image objects to display in the check run's output in the GitHub UI. Each object requires `alt` (alternative text), `image_url` (URL of the image), and an optional `caption`.
output__images.title: Output  Images

output__summary.description: A summary of the check run's findings. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
output__summary.title: Output  Summary

output__text.description: Detailed textual information about the check run's output. Supports Markdown. **Maximum length**: 65,535 characters.
output__text.title: Output  Text

output__title.description: A descriptive title for the output of the check run, displayed in the GitHub UI. For example, 'Linter Scan Summary'.
output__title.title: Output  Title

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

started_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) indicating when the check run began.
started_at.title: Started At

status.description: The current status of the check run. Only GitHub Actions can set `status` to `waiting`, `pending`, or `requested`.
status.title: Status

parameters.title: CreateACheckRunRequest

data.description: A dictionary representing the full check run object as created by the API. This includes fields like `id`, `node_id`, `head_sha`, `status`, `conclusion`, `name`, `details_url`, `external_id`, `started_at`, `completed_at`, `output` (containing summary, text, annotations, images), `app` (information about the GitHub App that created the check run), and `pull_requests` (an array of pull requests associated with the commit).
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CODESPACE_FOR_THE_AUTHENTICATED_USER
items.displayName: Create a codespace for the authenticated user
items.display_name: Create a codespace for the authenticated user
items.description: Creates a github codespace for the authenticated user, requiring a json request body with either `repository id` (integer) or a `pull request` object (containing `pull request number` (integer) and `repository id` (integer)).

parameters.description:
Request body for POST /user/codespaces.

Provide either:
- repository_id (int) + ref (string branch/commit/PR ref), or
- pull_request object with pull_request_number (int) and repository_id (int).

Other optional fields supported by the API (machine, location, devcontainer_path, etc.) can be added later if needed.

repository_id.description: Repository ID for the pull request.
repository_id.title: Repository Id

ref.description: Git ref (branch, tag, or commit SHA) to use for the codespace.
ref.title: Ref

repository_id.description: ID of the repository to create the codespace from.
repository_id.title: Repository Id

parameters.title: CreateACodespaceForTheAuthenticatedUserRequest

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CODESPACE_FROM_A_PULL_REQUEST
items.displayName: Create a codespace from a pull request
items.display_name: Create a codespace from a pull request
items.description: Creates a github codespace for an open pull request in a codespaces-enabled repository, with options to customize its configuration.

parameters.description: Request to create a GitHub Codespace from a pull request, specifying its configuration.

client_ip.description: Client's public IP address for location auto-detection if proxied and `geo` or `location` are not specified.
client_ip.title: Client Ip

devcontainer_path.description: Path to a `devcontainer.json` file in the repository that defines the development environment.
devcontainer_path.title: Devcontainer Path

geo.description: Geographic area for this codespace (e.g., `UsEast`, `EuropeWest`); supersedes `location`. If unspecified, typically IP-derived.
geo.title: Geo

idle_timeout_minutes.description: Minutes of inactivity after which the codespace is automatically stopped. A default timeout applies if unspecified.
idle_timeout_minutes.title: Idle Timeout Minutes

location.description: Requested geographic location (e.g., `EastUs`, `WestEurope`). This parameter is deprecated; use `geo`. If unspecified, location may be IP-derived.
location.title: Location

machine.description: Machine type for this codespace (e.g., `standardLinux`). Varies by CPU, RAM, storage. Uses default if unspecified.
machine.title: Machine

multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.description: Set to `true` to prevent GitHub from requesting additional repository permissions defined in `devcontainer.json`. Defaults to `false` (permissions will be requested).
multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.title: Multi Repo Permissions Opt Out

owner.description: The username of the account that owns the repository. This is case-insensitive.
owner.title: Owner

pull_number.description: The unique number identifying the pull request.
pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This is case-insensitive.
repo.title: Repo

retention_period_minutes.description: Retention period in minutes (0-43200, i.e., up to 30 days) for a stopped codespace. 0 means immediate deletion.
retention_period_minutes.title: Retention Period Minutes

working_directory.description: Working directory for the codespace upon opening. Defaults to the repository root if unspecified.
working_directory.title: Working Directory

parameters.title: CreateACodespaceFromAPullRequestRequest

data.description: Full details of the created codespace.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_CODESPACE_IN_A_REPOSITORY
items.displayName: Create a codespace in a repository
items.display_name: Create a codespace in a repository
items.description: Creates a github codespace for the authenticated user in a specified repository, which must be accessible and use a valid `devcontainer.json` if `devcontainer path` is specified.

parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateACodespaceInARepository`

client_ip.description: IP address to infer preferred region if `location` and `geo` are unspecified; useful for proxied requests.
client_ip.title: Client Ip

devcontainer_path.description: Path to a `devcontainer.json` in the repository; uses `.devcontainer/devcontainer.json` or `devcontainer.json` at root if not specified.
devcontainer_path.title: Devcontainer Path

display_name.description: Custom display name for the codespace; a default name is generated if not provided.
display_name.title: Display Name

geo.description: Geographic area for the codespace, replacing `location`; determined by user IP if not specified.
geo.title: Geo

idle_timeout_minutes.description: Minutes of inactivity before codespace auto-stops; uses a default timeout if not specified.
idle_timeout_minutes.title: Idle Timeout Minutes

location.description: Requested AWS region (best-effort, may differ); determined by user IP if not provided. Deprecated: use `geo`.
location.title: Location

machine.description: Machine type (CPU, RAM, storage). See 'List available machine types for a repository' action for options; uses a default type if not specified.
machine.title: Machine

multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.description: If `true`, opts out of granting multi-repository permissions from `devcontainer.json`. If unspecified or `false`, permissions are granted if requested.
multi_repo_permissions_opt_out.title: Multi Repo Permissions Opt Out

owner.description: Username or organization name owning the repository; not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: Git reference (e.g., branch name) for the codespace; uses repository's default branch if not provided.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: Name of the repository, without the `.git` extension; not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

retention_period_minutes.description: Minutes an idle (stopped) codespace is retained before auto-deletion (0-43200, i.e., up to 30 days); uses a default period if not specified.
retention_period_minutes.title: Retention Period Minutes

working_directory.description: Directory to use as default when codespace opens; uses repository root if not specified.
working_directory.title: Working Directory

parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateADeployment`

examples: Deploying new feature X to staging.

payload.title: Payload

repo.title: Repo

required_contexts.description: A list of status check contexts to verify against commit status checks before creating the deployment. If omitted or `null`, GitHub verifies all unique contexts. Pass an empty list `[]` to bypass all checks.

task.description: Specifies a task to execute, e.g., `deploy` or `deploy:migrations`.
task.title: Task

transient_environment.description: Specifies if the given environment is specific to this deployment and will no longer exist at some point in the future (e.g., a staging environment for a pull request). Set to `true` if the environment is temporary.

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_AN_ORGANIZATION_WEBHOOK
items.description: Creates a webhook for a github organization to deliver event notifications to a configured url.

parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAnOrganizationWebhook`

active.description: Boolean indicating if the webhook is active. `true` sends notifications, `false` does not. Defaults to `true`.
active.title: Active

config__content__type.description: The media type for serializing webhook payloads. Supported: `json`, `form`. GitHub API defaults to `form` if this field is not set or is `None`.
config__content__type.title: Config  Content  Type

config__insecure__ssl.description: Controls SSL certificate verification for `config_url`. '1' disables verification (not recommended), '0' enables. GitHub API defaults to '0' (verification enabled) if this field is not set or is `None`.
config__insecure__ssl.title: Config  Insecure  Ssl

config__password.description: Password for basic authentication if the webhook endpoint (`config_url`) requires it, corresponding to `config_username`.
config__password.title: Config  Password

config__secret.description: Optional secret for generating an HMAC hex digest for payload verification (X-Hub-Signature-256 header). If provided, this is used as the key.
config__secret.title: Config  Secret

config__url.description: The target URL for webhook payload delivery. This URL is a mandatory part of the webhook's `config` object and will receive POST requests for subscribed events.
config__url.title: Config  Url

config__username.description: Username for basic authentication if the webhook endpoint (`config_url`) requires it. Use only if your endpoint is protected by basic auth.
config__username.title: Config  Username

events.description: List of event names to trigger the webhook. Use `['*']` for all events. Defaults to `['push']` if not specified. See GitHub docs for event types.
events.title: Events

name.description: The name of the webhook. Must be "web" for organization webhooks.
name.title: Name

org.description: The name of the GitHub organization. This name is not case-sensitive.
org.title: Org

parameters.title: CreateAnOrganizationWebhookRequest

data.description: A dictionary containing the complete JSON representation of the created webhook object as returned by the GitHub API.
data.title: Data

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateAPullRequest`

base.description: The name of the branch you want the changes pulled into. This must be an existing branch on the current (target) repository. You cannot submit a pull request to one repository that requests a merge to a base branch of another repository.
base.title: Base

body.description: The detailed description or contents of the pull request.
examples: This PR introduces a new feature that does X, Y, and Z.
Fixes #42 by addressing the off-by-one error.

draft.description: Indicates whether the pull request should be created as a draft. Draft pull requests cannot be merged until marked as ready for review.
draft.title: Draft

head.description: The name of the branch where your changes are implemented. For cross-repository pull requests, namespace `head` with the source owner and branch, like `username:branch`.
head.title: Head

head_repo.description: The name of the repository (e.g., 'octocat/Hello-World') where the changes in the pull request were made. This field is required for cross-repository pull requests if both the source and target repositories are owned by the same organization but are different repositories.
head_repo.title: Head Repo

issue.description: The number of an existing issue in the repository to convert into a pull request. If provided, the issue's title and body may be used for the pull request. Required if `title` is not specified.
issue.title: Issue

maintainer_can_modify.description: Indicates whether maintainers of the upstream repository can modify the pull request. This is primarily relevant for pull requests originating from forks.
maintainer_can_modify.title: Maintainer Can Modify

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

title.description: The title of the new pull request. Required unless `issue` is specified.
title.title: Title

data.description: A dictionary containing the full representation of the created pull request.
data.title: Data

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_RELEASE
items.description: Creates a release in a github repository for a specified tag; the tag must be unique for published releases, and if a `discussion category name` is given, it must already exist.

body.description: A detailed description of the release. Markdown formatting is supported.
examples: This release includes new features X, Y, and bug fixes for Z.

# New Features
- Feature A
- Feature B
body.title: Body

discussion_category_name.description: If specified, a new discussion will be created in this category and linked to the release. The category must already exist in the repository's discussions.
discussion_category_name.title: Discussion Category Name

draft.description: Set to `true` to create an unpublished (draft) release. Defaults to `false`.
draft.title: Draft

generate_release_notes.description: Set to `true` to automatically generate the release title (`name`) and description (`body`) from the commit history since the last release. Defaults to `false`.
generate_release_notes.title: Generate Release Notes

make_latest.description: Specifies if this release should be marked as the latest for the repository. Valid values: 'true', 'false', 'legacy'. Defaults to 'true'. Draft releases and prereleases cannot be set as 'latest'.
make_latest.title: Make Latest

name.description: The title of the release. If omitted and `generate_release_notes` is false, it defaults to the `tag_name`.
name.title: Name

owner.description: The account owner of the repository (username or organization name). This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

prerelease.description: Set to `true` to identify this release as a pre-release. Defaults to `false`.
prerelease.title: Prerelease

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the .git extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tag_name.description: The name of the tag for this release. This tag must be unique for published releases.
tag_name.title: Tag Name

target_commitish.description: Specifies the commitish value (e.g., branch name, tag name, or commit SHA) from which the Git tag is created. Defaults to the repository's default branch if the tag specified in `tag_name` doesn't exist yet.
target_commitish.title: Target Commitish

data.description: Data from the action execution

assets.description: A list of assets attached to this release.

browser_download_url.description: The direct URL for downloading this asset via a web browser.
browser_download_url.title: Browser Download Url

content_type.description: The MIME type of the asset (e.g., 'application/zip', 'image/png').
content_type.title: Content Type

created_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp for when the asset was created.
created_at.title: Created At

download_count.description: The number of times this asset has been downloaded.
download_count.title: Download Count

id.description: The unique numerical identifier for this release asset.
id.title: Id

label.description: An optional, short, descriptive label for the asset.
label.title: Label

name.description: The filename of the release asset.
name.title: Name

node_id.description: The global Relay ID for this release asset.
node_id.title: Node Id

size.description: The size of the asset in bytes.
size.title: Size

state.description: The state of the release asset. Typically 'uploaded' for successfully uploaded assets.
state.title: State

updated_at.description: The ISO 8601 timestamp for when the asset was last updated.
updated_at.title: Updated At

uploader.description: Information about the user who uploaded a release asset. Inherits fields from ReleaseAuthor.

avatar_url.description: The URL for the user's avatar image.
avatar_url.title: Avatar Url

email.description: The publicly visible email address of the user. May be null.
email.title: Email

events_url.description: The API URL for the user's public events. Placeholder {/privacy} may be present.
events_url.title: Events Url

followers_url.description: The API URL for listing the user's followers.
followers_url.title: Followers Url

following_url.description: The API URL for listing users followed by this user. Placeholder {/other_user} may be present.
following_url.title: Following Url

gists_url.description: The API URL for the user's gists. Placeholder {/gist_id} may be present.
gists_url.title: Gists Url

gravatar_id.description: The Gravatar ID for the user. May be empty if the user does not use Gravatar.
gravatar_id.title: Gravatar Id

html_url.description: The URL to the user's profile page on GitHub.
html_url.title: Html Url

id.description: The unique numerical identifier for the user on GitHub.
id.title: Id

login.description: The GitHub username (login) of the user.
login.title: Login

name.description: The display name of the user. May be null.
name.title: Name

node_id.description: The global Relay ID for the user, used with GraphQL API.
node_id.title: Node Id

organizations_url.description: The API URL for the user's organization memberships.
organizations_url.title: Organizations Url

received_events_url.description: The API URL for events received by the user.
received_events_url.title: Received Events Url

repos_url.description: The API URL for the user's public repositories.
repos_url.title: Repos Url

site_admin.description: Indicates whether the user is a GitHub site administrator.
site_admin.title: Site Admin

starred_at.description: Timestamp indicating when the user performed a starring action related to a repository, if available in the context of this user object.
starred_at.title: Starred At

starred_url.description: The API URL for repositories starred by this user. Placeholders {/owner}{/repo} may be present.
starred_url.title: Starred Url

subscriptions_url.description: The API URL for the user's repository subscriptions.
subscriptions_url.title: Subscriptions Url

url.description: The API URL for this user's details.
url.title: Url

user_view_type.description: A string indicating the user's view type; its meaning might be context-dependent.
user_view_type.title: User View Type

uploader.title: ReleaseAssetUploader

url.description: The API URL for this release asset.
url.title: Url

items.description: Exchanges a user-to-server token for a new, fine-grained scoped access token for a github app, requiring `client id`, `access token`, either `target` or `target id`, and at least one permission; for repository-specific scoping, provide either `repositories` (names) or `repository ids` (ids), but not both.

parameters.description: Request schema for creating a new scoped access token for a GitHub App.

access_token.description: User-to-server access token to be exchanged for a new scoped token.

permissions__actions.description: Permission for GitHub Actions workflows, workflow runs, and artifacts. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__actions.title: Permissions  Actions

permissions__administration.description: Permission for repository administration (settings, teams, collaborators). Applies to target repositories.
permissions__administration.title: Permissions  Administration

permissions__checks.description: Permission for checks on code (e.g., CI statuses). Applies to target repositories.
permissions__checks.title: Permissions  Checks

permissions__codespaces.description: Permission for Codespaces. Applies to target user/organization if repositories are not specified, otherwise to target repositories.
permissions__codespaces.title: Permissions  Codespaces

permissions__contents.description: Permission for repository contents, commits, branches, downloads, releases, and merges. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__contents.title: Permissions  Contents

permissions__dependabot__secrets.description: Permission for Dependabot secrets for targeted repositories.
permissions__dependabot__secrets.title: Permissions  Dependabot  Secrets

permissions__deployments.description: Permission for deployments and deployment statuses. Applies to target repositories.
permissions__deployments.title: Permissions  Deployments

permissions__email__addresses.description: Permission to manage email addresses for the user account. Applies to target user.
permissions__email__addresses.title: Permissions  Email  Addresses

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_SNAPSHOT_OF_DEPENDENCIES_FOR_A_REPOSITORY
items.description: Creates a snapshot of a repository's dependencies to populate the github dependency graph and enable security alerts; `sha` must be a 40-character commit id, `ref` a fully qualified git reference (e.g., `refs/heads/main`), and `scanned` an iso 8601 timestamp.

parameters.description: Input for creating a dependency snapshot, capturing the repository's dependency state at a specific commit.

detector__name.description: Optional name of the tool used to detect dependencies.
detector__name.title: Detector  Name

detector__url.description: Optional URL of the detector tool used.
detector__url.title: Detector  Url

detector__version.description: Optional version of the detector tool used.
detector__version.title: Detector  Version

job__correlator.description: Optional string to group snapshots. For a given `job.correlator` and `detector.name`, only the 'latest' snapshot is current. Useful to distinguish detection runs (e.g., concatenating GITHUB_WORKFLOW and GITHUB_JOB).
job__correlator.title: Job  Correlator

job__html__url.description: Optional URL for the job that generated this snapshot.
job__html__url.title: Job  Html  Url

job__id.description: Optional external ID of the job that generated this snapshot.
job__id.title: Job  Id

manifests.description: Optional collection of package manifests (e.g., package-lock.json, pom.xml). Keys are manifest file names; values detail dependencies.
manifests.title: Manifests

metadata.description: Optional user-defined metadata for domain-specific information. Limited to 8 keys with scalar values (e.g., string, number, boolean).
metadata.title: Metadata

owner.description: Account owner of the repository (name is not case-sensitive).
owner.title: Owner

ref.description: Git reference (fully qualified, e.g., `refs/heads/main`) of the repository branch/tag that triggered this snapshot.
ref.title: Ref

repo.description: Repository name, without `.git` extension (name is not case-sensitive).
repo.title: Repo

scanned.description: UTC timestamp (ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ) when the snapshot was taken.
scanned.title: Scanned

sha.description: Commit SHA (maximum 40 characters) associated with this dependency snapshot.
sha.title: Sha

version.description: Version of the dependency snapshot submission, typically of the manifest or lock file format.
version.title: Version

parameters.title: CreateASnapshotOfDependenciesForARepositoryRequest

data.description: ID of the created snapshot and a confirmation message.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_A_TREE
items.description: Creates a new git tree object in a repository, defining file/directory structure by specifying tree entries, optionally building on a `base tree` sha; all provided shas must be valid.

parameters.description: Request schema for `CreateATree`

base_tree.description: SHA1 of an existing Git tree object to use as a base. If provided, its entries are combined with `tree` entries, where `tree` entries overwrite those from `base_tree` with the same path. Typically the SHA1 of the latest commit's tree for new branch changes. If omitted, the new tree is built from `tree` entries; files from the parent commit's tree not in `tree` are treated as deleted.
base_tree.title: Base Tree

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: The name of the repository without the `.git` extension. The name is not case sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tree.description: List of objects defining the tree structure. Each object (node) requires `path` (string), `mode` (string; e.g., '100644' file, '100755' executable, '040000' subdirectory/tree, '160000' submodule, '120000' symlink), and `type` (string: 'blob', 'tree', or 'commit'). For new/updated blobs, provide `content` (UTF-8 string). For existing objects or `tree`/`commit` types, provide `sha` (string). To delete, specify `path`, `mode`, `type`, and set `sha` to `null`.
tree.title: Tree

parameters.title: CreateATreeRequest

data.description: A dictionary representing the created Git tree object. It includes the `sha` and `url` of the new tree, an array of `tree` items (nodes in the tree), and a `truncated` boolean flag indicating if the number of items in the tree array exceeded the maximum limit and was cut short.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.description: Creates or updates an organization secret for github actions, requiring its value to be pre-encrypted via libsodium using the organization's public key.

parameters.description: Request schema for creating or updating an organization secret.

encrypted_value.description: Value for the secret, pre-encrypted using LibSodium with the organization's public key (obtained from 'Get an organization public key' endpoint). Required if creating a new secret or updating its value.
encrypted_value.title: Encrypted Value

key_id.description: ID of the public key (from 'Get an organization public key' endpoint) used for encryption. Required if `encrypted_value` is provided.
key_id.title: Key Id

org.description: The organization name. The name is not case sensitive.
org.title: Org

secret_name.description: The name of the secret.
secret_name.title: Secret Name

selected_repository_ids.description: List of repository IDs that can access this secret. Required and only applicable when `visibility` is 'selected'.
selected_repository_ids.title: Selected Repository Ids

visibility.description: Controls which repositories can access the secret. If 'selected', `selected_repository_ids` must be provided.
visibility.title: Visibility

parameters.title: CreateOrUpdateAnOrganizationSecretRequest

data.description: API response. Typically an empty body for successful creation (201) or update (204); may contain data for errors.
data.title: Data

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_CREATE_OR_UPDATE_FILE_CONTENTS
items.description: Creates a new file or updates an existing file in a github repository; provide `sha` to update an existing file, otherwise a new file is created.

parameters.description: Request schema for creating or updating a file's contents in a GitHub repository.

author__date.description: Author's timestamp (ISO 8601 format). Defaults to committer's date if author details are provided but date is not.
author__date.title: Author  Date

author__email.description: Author's email. If specified, `author_name` is also required. Defaults to committer details; if all committer/author details omitted, GitHub uses authenticated user.
author__email.title: Author  Email

author__name.description: Author's name. If specified, `author_email` is also required. Defaults to committer details; if all committer/author details omitted, GitHub uses authenticated user.
author__name.title: Author  Name

branch.description: The branch name. Defaults to the repository‚Äôs default branch if omitted.
branch.title: Branch

committer__date.description: Committer's commit timestamp (ISO 8601 format). Defaults to current time if committer details are provided but date is not.
committer__date.title: Committer  Date

committer__email.description: Committer's email. If specified, `committer_name` is also required. GitHub uses authenticated user if all committer/author details omitted.
committer__email.title: Committer  Email

committer__name.description: Committer's name. If specified, `committer_email` is also required. GitHub uses authenticated user if all committer/author details omitted.
committer__name.title: Committer  Name

content.description: The new file content, Base64 encoded. For example, to upload the text 'Hello World', use 'SGVsbG8gV29ybGQ='.
content.title: Content

message.description: The commit message for this file creation or update.
message.title: Message

owner.description: The account owner of the repository (not case sensitive).
owner.title: Owner

path.description: The full path to the file in the repository, including the filename and extension.
path.title: Path

repo.description: The name of the repository (not case sensitive, without the `.git` extension).
repo.title: Repo

sha.description: The blob SHA of the file being replaced. Required to update an existing file; omit to create a new file.
sha.title: Sha

parameters.title: CreateOrUpdateFileContentsRequest

error.description: Error if any occurred during the execution of the action
error.title: Error

successful.description: Whether or not the action execution was successful or not
successful.title: Successful

items.name: GITHUB_GENERATE_RELEASE_NOTES_CONTENT_FOR_A_RELEASE
items.displayName: Generate release notes content for a release
items.display_name: Generate release notes content for a release
items.description: Generates markdown release notes content (listing changes, pull requests, and contributors) for a github repository release, customizable via tags and a configuration file.

parameters.description: Request schema for generating release notes content for a GitHub release.

configuration_file_path.description: Specifies a path to a configuration file in the repository (e.g., `.github/release.yml`) containing settings for generating release notes. If unspecified, GitHub looks for a configuration file at ".github/release.yml" or ".github/release.yaml". If no such file is found, default settings are used.
configuration_file_path.title: Configuration File Path

owner.description: The username or organization name that owns the repository. This field is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

previous_tag_name.description: The name of the previous tag to use as the starting point for the release notes. This manually specifies the range of changes to be included. If omitted, GitHub will attempt to automatically determine the previous release.
previous_tag_name.title: Previous Tag Name

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This field is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tag_name.description: The tag name for which the release notes are to be generated. This can be an existing tag or a new tag name.
tag_name.title: Tag Name

target_commitish.description: Specifies the commitish value (e.g., a branch name, tag name, or commit SHA) that will be the target for the release's tag. This is required if the `tag_name` does not reference an existing tag. It is ignored if `tag_name` already exists.
target_commitish.title: Target Commitish

parameters.title: GenerateReleaseNotesContentForAReleaseRequest

data.description: A dictionary containing the generated release notes. Expected keys are 'name' (the title of the release notes) and 'body' (the Markdown content of the release notes).

examples.body:
## Changes
- Fix for bug #123
- New feature X

## Contributors
- @user1
examples.name: Release v1.0.1

before.description: A pagination cursor. Returns activity items that occurred before this cursor. This cursor is typically obtained from the `Link` header in a previous API response. per_page.title: Per Page

items.name: GITHUB_MANAGE_ACCESS_CONTROL_FOR_ORGANIZATION_CODESPACES
items.displayName: Manage access control for organization codespaces
items.display_name: Manage access control for organization codespaces
items.description: Sets the codespaces access control policy for a github organization, determining which members can use them.

parameters.description: Request model for managing Codespaces access control within an organization.

org.description: The name of the GitHub organization. This field is not case-sensitive.
org.title: Org

selected_usernames.description: A list of GitHub usernames who should have access to Codespaces. This field is required and used only when `visibility` is set to `selected_members`. Providing a list here will replace any existing list of selected usernames.
selected_usernames.title: Selected Usernames

visibility.description:
Defines which users can access Codespaces within the organization.
`disabled`: Codespaces are disabled for all users in the organization.
`selected_members`: Only users specified in `selected_usernames` can access Codespaces.
`all_members`: All members of the organization can access Codespaces.
`all_members_and_outside_collaborators`: All members and outside collaborators can access Codespaces.
visibility.title: Visibility

parameters.title: ManageAccessControlForOrganizationCodespacesRequest

data.description: Response data, which is typically empty as a successful (HTTP 204) response has no body.

Optionally, specify `line` (or `start_line` for multi-line), and `side` (or `start_side`) for diff location. `position` is deprecated; use `line`. Example: `[{'path': 'file.py', 'line': 10, 'body': 'Refactor this.'}]`

start_side.title: SideEnm

comments.title: Comments

Specifies the level of access workflows outside this repository have to its actions and reusable workflows.
- `none`: Actions and reusable workflows are accessible only from workflows within this repository.
- `user`: Actions and reusable workflows can be shared with other private repositories owned by the same user.

items.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_A_CHECK_RUN
items.description: Updates an existing check run for a specific commit in a repository, allowing modifications to its status, conclusion, output, and other details.

parameters.description: Request schema for `UpdateACheckRun`

check_run_id.description: The unique identifier of the check run.
check_run_id.title: Check Run Id

completed_at.description: Timestamp of when the check run completed (ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).
completed_at.title: Completed At

details_url.title: Details Url

external_id.description: Reference for the run on the integrator's system.
external_id.title: External Id

name.description: Name of the check (e.g., "code-coverage").
name.title: Name

output__annotations.description: Adds line-specific analysis information, visible in PRs. Max 50 per request (appended to existing). GitHub Actions: 10 warnings/10 errors per step.
output__annotations.title: Output  Annotations

output__images.description: Images for the output, displayed in the GitHub PR UI.
output__images.title: Output  Images

output__summary.description: Summary of the output, can contain Markdown. Required if the `output` object is provided.
output__summary.title: Output  Summary

output__text.description: Text for the output, can contain Markdown.
output__text.title: Output  Text

owner.description: Account owner of the repository (not case sensitive).
owner.title: Owner

repo.description: Repository name without the `.git` extension (not case sensitive).
repo.title: Repo

started_at.description: Timestamp of when the check run started (ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`).
started_at.title: Started At

status.description: Current status of the check run. Only GitHub Actions can set `waiting`, `pending`, or `requested`.
status.title: Status

error.title: Error

config__secret.description: Secret key for HMAC digest to ensure payload integrity. Refer to GitHub documentation on delivery headers for details.

items.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_A_PULL_REQUEST
items.description: Updates an existing pull request, allowing changes to attributes like title, body, state, base branch, and maintainer modification settings.

body.description: The new contents of the pull request. To remove the body, pass an empty string. If None, the body remains unchanged.

maintainer_can_modify.description: Indicates whether [maintainers can modify](https://docs.github.com/articles/allowing-changes-to-a-pull-request-branch-created-from-a-fork/) the pull request. If None, this setting remains unchanged.

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.

pull_number.description: The unique number that identifies the pull request within the repository.
pull_number.title: Pull Number

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.

state.description: The new state of the pull request. Can be 'open' or 'closed'. If None, the state remains unchanged.

title.description: The new title for the pull request. If None, the title remains unchanged.

items.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_A_RELEASE
items.description: Updates an existing release in a github repository, allowing modification of its attributes; if linking a discussion, the `discussion category name` must refer to an existing category in the repository.

parameters.description: Request schema for `UpdateARelease`

body.description: Text describing the contents of the release. Supports GitHub Flavored Markdown.
examples: This release includes performance improvements and bug fixes related to user authentication.
body.title: Body

discussion_category_name.description: If specified, a discussion of this category is created and linked to the release. The category must already exist in the repository. This parameter is ignored if a discussion is already linked to the release. For more information, see "[Managing categories for discussions in your repository](https://docs.github.com/discussions/managing-discussions-for-your-community/managing-categories-for-discussions-in-your-repository)."
discussion_category_name.title: Discussion Category Name

draft.description: Set to `true` to mark the release as a draft, or `false` to publish it. Default: `false`.
draft.title: Draft

make_latest.description: Specifies whether this release should be set as the latest release for the repository. Accepts 'true', 'false', or 'legacy'. Drafts and pre-releases cannot be set as latest. Defaults to `true` for newly published releases. `legacy` specifies that the latest release should be determined based on the release creation date and higher semantic version.
make_latest.title: Make Latest

name.description: The title of the release.
name.title: Name

owner.description: The account owner of the repository. This name is not case-sensitive.
owner.title: Owner

prerelease.description: Set to `true` to identify the release as a pre-release, or `false` for a full release. Default: `false`.
prerelease.title: Prerelease

release_id.description: The unique identifier of the release to be updated.
release_id.title: Release Id

repo.description: The name of the repository, without the `.git` extension. This name is not case-sensitive.
repo.title: Repo

tag_name.description: The name of the tag. This can be an existing tag or a new tag name.
tag_name.title: Tag Name

target_commitish.description: Specifies the commitish value (e.g., branch name or commit SHA) that determines where the Git tag is created from. Can be any branch or commit SHA. This parameter is unused if the Git tag specified by `tag_name` already exists. Defaults to the repository's default branch if omitted.
target_commitish.title: Target Commitish

items.name: GITHUB_UPDATE_A_TEAM
items.description: Updates a team's settings (e.g., name, description, privacy, parent team) within a github organization, identified by its slug and organization name.

parameters.description: Parameters to update a team's settings in a GitHub organization.

description.description: New team description; an empty string clears the existing description.
examples: Responsible for all frontend development aspects of Project X
description.title: Description

name.description: New display name for the team.
name.title: Name

notification_setting.description:
The notification setting the team has chosen. Editing teams without specifying this parameter leaves `notification_setting` intact.
  - `notifications_enabled`: Team members receive notifications when the team is @mentioned.
  - `notifications_disabled`: No one receives notifications for team @mentions.
notification_setting.title: Notification Setting

org.description: The organization's name (case-insensitive).
org.title: Org

parent_team_id.description: The unique identifier (ID) of an existing team to set as this team's parent. This establishes a nested team structure. To remove an existing parent team relationship and make this a top-level team, explicitly pass `null` for this field (e.g., by setting this parameter to Python `None`). If this parameter is not provided in the request, the current parent team, if any, remains unchanged.
parent_team_id.title: Parent Team Id

permission.description: **Deprecated**. Default permission (pull, push, or admin) for new repositories added to this team. This may be removed in future versions.
permission.title: Permission

privacy.description:
The desired privacy level for the team. Editing teams without specifying this parameter leaves `privacy` intact. When a team is nested, the `privacy` for parent teams cannot be `secret`.
  - For a non-nested team:
    - `secret`: Visible only to organization owners and members of this team.
    - `closed`: Visible to all members of this organization.
  - For a parent or child team:
    - `closed`: Visible to all members of this organization.
privacy.title: Privacy

team_slug.description: The team's unique slug identifier (typically URL-friendly version of team name).
team_slug.title: Team Slug

parameters.title: UpdateATeamRequest

data.description: The full, updated team object as returned by the GitHub API.
data.title: Data

items.name: GMAIL_FETCH_EMAILS
items.description: Fetches a list of email messages from a gmail account, supporting filtering, pagination, and optional full content retrieval.

ids_only.description: If true, only returns message IDs from the list API without fetching individual message details. Fastest option for getting just message IDs and thread IDs.

include_payload.description: Set to true to include full message payload (headers, body, attachments); false for metadata only.

items.name: GOOGLEDRIVE_CREATE_DRIVE
items.description: Tool to create a new shared drive. use when you need to programmatically create a new shared drive for collaboration or storage.

backgroundImageFile.description: An image file and cropping parameters from which a background image for this shared drive is set. This is a write only field; it can only be set on drive.drives.update requests that don't set themeId. When specified, all fields of the backgroundImageFile must be set.

id.description: The ID of an image file in Google Drive to use for the background.
id.title: Id

width.description: The width of the cropped image in the range: 0.0 <= width <= 1.0.
width.title: Width

xCoordinate.description: The X coordinate of the cropped image in the range: 0.0 <= xCoordinate <= 1.0.
xCoordinate.title: X Coordinate

yCoordinate.description: The Y coordinate of the cropped image in the range: 0.0 <= yCoordinate <= 1.0.
yCoordinate.title: Y Coordinate

backgroundImageFile.title: BackgroundImageFile

colorRgb.description: The color of this shared drive as an RGB hex string. It can only be set on a drive.drives.update request that does not set themeId.
colorRgb.title: Color Rgb

hidden.description: Whether the shared drive is hidden from default view.
hidden.title: Hidden

name.description: The name of this shared drive.
name.title: Name

requestId.description: An ID, such as a random UUID, which uniquely identifies this user's request for idempotent creation of a shared drive. A repeated request by the same user and with the same request ID will avoid creating duplicates by attempting to create the same shared drive. If the shared drive already exists a 409 error will be returned.
requestId.title: Request Id

themeId.description: The ID of the theme from which the background image and color will be set. The set of possible driveThemes can be retrieved from a drive.about.get response. When not specified on a drive.drives.create request, a random theme is chosen from which the background image and color are set. This is a write-only field; it can only be set on requests that don't set colorRgb or backgroundImageFile.
themeId.title: Theme Id

data.description: Data from the action execution

backgroundImageLink.description: A short-lived link to this shared drive's background image.
backgroundImageLink.title: Background Image Link

items.description: Tool to list a user's files and folders in google drive. use this to search or browse for files and folders based on various criteria.

driveId.title: Drive Id

folderId.title: Folder Id

includeItemsFromAllDrives.title: Include Items From All Drives

includePermissionsForView.title: Include Permissions For View

orderBy.description: A comma-separated list of sort keys. Valid keys include 'createdTime', 'folder', 'modifiedByMeTime', 'modifiedTime', 'name', 'name_natural', 'quotaBytesUsed', 'recency', 'sharedWithMeTime', 'starred', 'viewedByMeTime'. Each key sorts in ascending order by default, but can be reversed with the 'desc' modifier (e.g., 'modifiedTime desc').

items.name: GOOGLEDRIVE_UPDATE_FILE_PUT
items.description: Updates file metadata. uses patch semantics (partial update) as per google drive api v3. use this tool to modify attributes of an existing file like its name, description, or parent folders. note: this action currently supports metadata updates only. file content updates require multipart/related upload and are not yet implemented.

add_parents.description: A comma-separated list of parent IDs to add.
add_parents.title: Add Parents

description.description: A short description of the file.
examples: Updated version of the project proposal.
description.title: Description

file_id.description: The ID of the file to update.
file_id.title: File Id

keep_revision_forever.description: Whether to set this revision of the file to be kept forever. This is only applicable to files with binary content in Google Drive. Only 200 revisions for the file can be kept forever. If the limit is reached, try deleting pinned revisions.
keep_revision_forever.title: Keep Revision Forever

mime_type.description: The MIME type of the file. Google Drive will attempt to automatically detect an appropriate value from uploaded content if no value is provided. The value cannot be changed unless a new revision is uploaded.
mime_type.title: Mime Type

name.description: The name of the file.
name.title: Name

ocr_language.description: A language hint for OCR processing during image import (ISO 639-1 code).
ocr_language.title: Ocr Language

remove_parents.description: A comma-separated list of parent IDs to remove.

starred.description: Whether the user has starred the file.
starred.title: Starred

supports_all_drives.title: Supports All Drives

use_domain_admin_access.title: Use Domain Admin Access

viewers_can_copy_content.description: Whether viewers are prevented from copying content of the file.
viewers_can_copy_content.title: Viewers Can Copy Content

writers_can_share.description: Whether writers can share the document with other users.
writers_can_share.title: Writers Can Share

data.description: Data from the action execution

app_properties.description: A collection of arbitrary key-value pairs which are private to the requesting app.

capabilities.title: Capabilities

description.description: A short description of the file.

trashed.description: Whether the file has been trashed, either explicitly or from a trashed parent folder.

video_media_metadata.description: Metadata about video media. This will only be present for video types.

viewed_by_me.description: Whether the file has been viewed by this user.

viewed_by_me_time.title: Viewed By Me Time
